data.title: Behind Oando Energy's rise to $940-million from $2-million in eight years
data.meta_description: A case study in the benefits of perseverance. That’s the appropriate term to describe the path taken by Oando Energy Resources over the past eight plus years
data.text:
Article content

A case study in the benefits of perseverance. That’s the appropriate term to describe the path taken by Oando Energy Resources over the past eight plus years.

Consider how it started: Through Exile Resources in late 2005 it raised $2-million in an initial public offering. It followed that up with a $820,000 flow through raise, owned a right to earn a stake in a property in Alberta and it planned to make a joint application for a property in Ghana and Cameroon.

Consider this week’s news: It has received the approval of the Nigerian government for the US$1.65-billion acquisition of the upstream oil and gas business owned in Nigeria by ConocoPhillips. Oando (OER/TSX), which closed Thursday at $1.67, has a market cap of $940-million.

“It has been a long journey, wherein we kept faith with our strategy and executed every milestone diligently. This acquisition satisfies our criteria for assets in production, as well as excellent appraisal and exploration prospects. The coast now stands clear for us to immediately complete the acquisition,” said Wale Tinubu, OER’s delighted chairman, adding the acquisition is expected to be completed by month end.

If that deadline is met, then the closing will come more than 18 months after the acquisition, largely onshore assets that will give Oando a 20% stake. Italy’s Agip Oil owns 20% and the government the 60% balance.

But to get to the stage where a TSX-Venture listed company, which had market cap at the time of $150-million, opted to try and buy an operation more than 10 times its size, Oando changed, adapted and took some risks. But there is at least one constant: Chris Harrop, a former analyst/investment, has been a director from day one. Harrop couldn’t be reached for comment.

Here are the key milestones.

• November 2006. After striking out in pursuing opportunities in Cameroon and Ghana, Exile strikes a deal to acquire, through a farm-in, a 40% stake in an oil and gas discovery in Nigeria, the so-called Akepo field. It bought the stake in the undeveloped field from a Nigerian oil company, Sogenal Ltd.

• Oct. 2009. Exile and Sonegal complete a deal where Nigerian-based Oando plc is granted 75% of Exile’s 40% interest in the Akepo field “in return for funding Exile’s past costs, and financing the future development of the project.”

As things turned out, that farm-in was a turning point for Exile. It gave the company exposure to a large Nigerian company and allowed the two to work together – and build a relationship. It also paved the way for Exile’s next transaction.

• July 2011. Oando inquires, informally, about a broader relationship. In time, a deal is hatched where Exile would acquire all of Oando’s upstream exploration and producing assets in exchange for stock. One month later the parties announce an intention to proceed. Oando’s market cap is less than $150-million

• July 2012. The deal – effectively a reverse takeover – is completed. Because Exile is required to issue so many shares, it consolidates its stock on a one new share for 16.28 old shares. Even so, it issues 100 million new shares. Exile changed its name and the shares were listed on the TSX.
